Comment: Many Asian women did indeed provide “comfort” services to the Japanese Imperial Forces during World War II, but I do not believe they did it at the point of a gun nor was it sexual slavery.    Throughout history, military forces have had no problem finding “comfort women” regardless of the country in which they operated and they were able to find them without kidnapping, coercion or threats of any kind.  Wars create horrible conditions which cause people to resort to often unthinkable means to survive.  For many women, it was the use of their bodies, and there usually was more supply than demand.  I personally witness this during the Korean War and during two years in Vietnam.  Some members of the Imperial Japanese forces no doubt forced women to have sex, which, of course, is rape, but I believe the “comfort women” who served the Imperial Japanese forces in brothels that sprung up and operated near Japanese bases did so voluntarily for pay.

Comment: Not to be too anal, but you mean VPSO (Village Public Safety Officer), not VSPO. And I believe Wassillie, the victim, was a VPO (Village Police Officer), not a VPSO. There is a big difference. A VPSO goes through state training & is recognized & supervised & paid by the state. There are way more VPOs than VPSOs. VPOs get a lot less training, & none of it is from the state that I know of. VPOs get lower pay, & VPOs are not officially recognized by the state due to the state's  opposition to tribal sovereignty. VPOs are paid & supervised by tribal councils. VPOs have high turnover & are often very young guys. VPSOs are meant to be a career option & have longer term professionals, generally. Both jobs are very tough & involve putting yourself in danger without a gun. High stress & low pay. Lots of alcohol-fueled domestic disputes, sometimes relatives. 

And to #3, yes the booze came from Bethel, the only hub here. The villages all vote to be dry but BET lets it pour in & profits from it.

Comment: My father was American Indian who was born and raised on a reservation in New Mexico. He entered the Army and was sent to the Aleutians Islands during the war. When he came home he talked often about the war there and conditions on the islands. Mostly about there being no trees and how the wind seemed to drive some of the men mad. But what I remembered most and never forgot, was him telling me about what happened to the Aleut people. He use to tell us that they were like us but they had been sent away to "camps" like what they had done to the Japanese people he had gone to high school with, who went to camps, loosing their homes and the carrot and lettuce fields they had owned.
 I think he told us this because he wanted us to know and be aware it could happen to us too. I think he told us because he wanted us to remember because few people outside the Aleuts and Army knew about what had been done to them.
 He told us about the Navajo code talkers before knowledge of them was public.

Comment: Hi Cydney. The 60's were very different for me. My family had moved to a much bigger town and larger school district. My elementary and intermediate years were done in a small 2 room school One teacher taught 1-4th grade and the other taught 5th-8th grade. Our bus driver was our music, PE and art teacher, so it was like a big family. The kids in the 4th grade and 8th grade, became assistant instructors and help the younger kids out, so the teacher never had to stop the lessons. It worked very well, not to mention it helped create a sense of citizenship and community. We can never go back to those days and I'm sure glad I don't have to attend the schools we have today. There are some lessons to learn from those times but education today doesn't understand the concept nor do they have a base for such perception. It can't be fixed but I feel bad for the youngsters now days. How is it that any 2-3 year old can tell you what they want to be but by the 6th grade they no longer care!

Comment: Nick - I would be delighted if climate activists were showing up to argue for both density and housing affordability. Instead, they are mostly not showing up to the comprehensive plan hearings at all. Density, as Angus Duncan of the state climate change commission points out, is key to climate policy. If 7,00 people live within walking distance of each other, a grocery store will spring up to serve them that they can walk to, rather than drive. Density is critical to the viability of transit; the reason the New York subway system is economically viable is that there are a lot of people per stop. I think it's important for people who care about the climate to explain that to their fellow citizens. As to gentrification, cause gentrification; what causes gentrification is rich people moving here. If we built zero new housing, the rich people moving in would still drive up the price of the existing housing.

Comment: Parks Canada's  permanent budget is approximately $500 million of which approximately 75% comes from  funds voted by Parliament and 25% from revenues generated by the Agency, primarily user fees.  This year though,  Parks Canada’s budget  is $1.15 billion, reflecting one-time funding specifically for infrastructure.  However, operating the parks, including building/maintaining  trails, camp sites and other features is vitally dependent on user fees.   As Canada's budget deficit climbs from the promised $10 billion to upwards of $30-40 billion, Parks will feel much pain once the inevitable cuts come along. 

Parks Canada is   responsible for about $16 billion in built out assets, including highways through the parks.   Much has been done to build up the Trans Canada highway through Banff park but much remains to be done elsewhere across the country.   A lot of pressures exist on our parks, removing vital revenue should not be one of them.

Comment: I did the same work looking at the returns of HFR Energy and Commodity hedge funds versus all equity long short hedge funds.  In HFR inclusion is voluntary and so self selection implies that weak hands will not report.  Hedge funds are a better metric than 90 years of data .  First, the 90 year period it too long and not representative of the world today. Second, and more importantly, investor behavior counts.

I found from 1995 to 2015 that energy and commodity hedge funds were more volatile, had high correlations to the broad market, interestingly higher than to commodities themselves and were poor risk adjusted investments.  

Finally, if one looks solely at gold stocks you will see that they lag the rise in gold on the upside and often drop more quickly. I have not done the work on the whole universe so cannot comment but suspect that the confluence of political risk, operational risk and unknown reserves may make this true in other sectors of commodities too.

Comment: It's hard for me to understand Oregon's "water shortage" when at the south entrance of the Megler Bridge in Astoria and looking across three miles of mostly fresh Columbia water flowing under it out to the ocean.

The southern parts of Oregon, the eastern heavily grazed portion outside the well-watered Columbia Basin and now in extreme draught ... that's a completely different story. Increasing warmth, lack of water, and chronic lack of nutritious graze is already taking a toll on locally ranched beef. Other western states have similar problems, as do countries like Brazil and Australia. The result? Beef prices continue rise and more meat eaters turn to chicken.

Having worked in lifelong natural resource conservation, what I fear more for Oregon than cattle grazers and beef eaters is a massive water take over by a dryer, wealthier, more politically powerful state like California to irrigate more fruit and nut crops.

Comment: Accelerated weekly payments of $500 will save you significantly amounts of interest over paying $2,167 per month.  Even accelerated bi-weekly payments of $1,000 will yield substantial benefits.  But the equivalent amount paid on a monthly basis is certainly not virtually the same thin.

In addition to the benefit of 52 payments a year accelerated weekly also means you are drawing down your mortgage every week rather than every month.  Over a 25 amortization period that amounts to about $22K in interest savings on a $150K mortgage.  The reason - interest is computed daily regardless of your payment frequency.  

So yes if you could pay hourly it would be even better.

Comment: Dividing the problems in Human Services will not solve the problems in the GOA. There is a culture of no accountability and no transparency that indicates to this citizen that simply changing the political party from PC to NDP did not solve the problems in performance.

Nor do I see satisfactory results from the two school board systems--public and Catholic. We could have one health authority and one super school board. These changes are necessary.

Simply dividing up a department as Ms. Notley has done means nothing without the political will to make change happen.

Those actions, by definition, will blunt whatever gains min wage workers might have gotten with these increases,.

Government has produced a plethora of programs across all areas to help min wage workers.  There's not much else they can do which is why they turned to huge increases in the min wage.  People who work at min wage jobs do so primarily because they don't have the skills to get higher paying jobs. Comment: garycrum, you question my etymology of "sucks," so I provide this: http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=suck  The noteworthy quote from that linked source is: "Meaning "do fellatio" is first recorded 1928. Slang sense of "be contemptible" first attested 1971 (the underlying notion is of fellatio)." I can't imagine much "street racing or traffic light racing" was being done in the USA in 1928, even though the first traffic light was installed in August 1914 in Cleveland, Ohio. It is interesting to note that the Online Etymology Dictionary link I provided doesn't include the derivation you got from the Urban Dictionary. The derivation I have quoted has now been in use for 89 years, and the derisive "be contemptible" connotation has now been in use for 46 years. Consider: http://womenshistory.about.com/od/feminism/a/Feminism-in-1971.htm — perhaps the derision was a backlash to Bella Abzug, Betty Friedan and Gloria Steinem founding the National Women’s Political Caucus in 1971.

Comment: A dividend should be determined by whatever remains after the imposition of a 2% income tax, 2% sales tax, and the use of 4% of the permanent fund's balance.   If those revenue sources exceed expenses, then pay the residual in the form f a dividend.   If they do not, then cut spending accordingly.   Every year, Alaskans can assess our financial situation by the amount of dividend they receive.    Alaskans can then make an informed choice:   lower spending or increase revenue.   But in all events, we'll have a balanced budget to which everyone who lives here, works here, or visits here, contributes a fair share.   That seems to be the most prudent way to approach our finances while still keeping everyone involved and still paying dividends when we can.

Comment: Learning left foot braking is a useful skill to have especially when highly precise low speed manoeuvring is required such as hooking up a trailer or in conditions of low traction or easing into tight spots. Using the brake to control the speed of the vehicle is more precise than using the accelerator and in conditions of low traction will help both drive wheels to turn rather than spinning one. This technique is called Controlled Throttle Management(CTM) and this is how it is done. Press hard on the brake pedal and shift into the appropriate gear. Gradually increase the throttle till the car is trying to move. Now with light removal and application of the brake, the car can be moved in tight increments with precise control of speed and position. Very little movement of the brake pedal is required and the throttle needs to be held at a constant engine speed - usually about 1000 rpm. When connecting trailers I even shift my truck into 4 low for even more precise control.

Comment: Scientific methodologies catch research errors whether intentional or unintentional.
I know PIs who do hands on checks of the research of grad students and post docs to prevent errors. Other PIs push grad students who do not have enough experience to resist or spot errors.  For example, I knew a grad student who had spent 4 years of their life attempting to do something that was based on an incorrect result.  They needed to verify that result before doing all the other work.  The error would have been caught earlier so they could have not wasted time and money but sometime time and money are problems for doing verification experiments.
The believe that the main conclusions in area as large as global climate would survive as incorrect information for any period of time reflects an lack of knowledge of scientific methodologies.

Comment: "Greens with a mere 16% of the popular vote, now wield a power vastly out of proportion to their percentage of votes."

The Greens are wielding that power in our CURRENT system. 

I note you are conveniently omitting the fact that the Greens got 16.5% of the votes and yet they're getting only 3.5% of the seats. Though they might hold the balance of power, they're still short-changed for representation.

This not a partisan issue.

Federal conservative party in 1993 got ~16% of the votes and wound up with ~1% of the seats. 

The status quo might favor a party I support, but I can't defend that outcome.

And cut the fear mongering: there are plenty of examples of functional democracies that have proportional systems. 

At the provincial and federal level, we very typically have "majority" governance that is secured with <40% of votes. 

The "stability" the present system offers ONLY exists because the system often lets elected officials ignore the voting will of the majority of voters.

Comment: You receive solar radiation constantly. During periods of higher solar activity, those very solar storms are responsible for modulating the cosmic radiation. Comment: Janette, I went to school in Michigan from the late 1960s to the middle 1980s.  And while I was almost a straight-A student, I did have a handful of classes in high school for which I received a "B", and a handful more in college in which (for various reasons relating to bad attitude, not aptitude) I received one "C", one "D" and one "E".  Nowhere was a failing grade an "F", which seems utterly nonsensical to me, skipping the "E" in favor of an "F".  Even at the University of Michigan, which had students from all over the USA as well as the world, nobody seemed to express surprise at the grade of "E" (which was admittedly a very rare grade to receive at the university level in a course, although a certain percentage of test scores were regularly an "E").

I have read a number of references to the grade of "F" since living in Alaska, but always assumed that it was either an error (meant to be an "E") or some kind of joke --- like receiving an "E-", even lower than a failing grade.

Comment: As a former renter in PA, I know the challenge of finding a rental at a price commensurate with condition. Rents are skewed high compared with incomes and the cost of buying, and inventory is scarce. I found myself in constant competition with Coast Guard renters. The local rental agencies told me the CG enjoys easy approval, whereas the rest of us go through lengthy background checks, even when our incomes are clearly sufficient. By the time that's done, the rental has been filled. Rinse and repeat.

Many rentals are owned by people who either no longer live here or inherited the house. They tend to do minimal maintenance while charging premium-plus rents. 

And forget about your beloved pet. PA landlords are intensely unfriendly to pets, even when one offers to pay a substantial deposit. 

If fully employed people are having such challenges, imagine how it is for people trying to climb out of homelessness. We need to work together to find creative, effective solutions for all.

There are many reasons to dislike the CAD.  Let us count the ways...
1.  The Canadian government is on a spending spree to stimulate domestic growth and will compete with private interests to borrow money, pressuring interest rates higher.
2.  Heavily indebted Canadians can't tolerate higher interest rates, so the Bank of Canada will try to sit on its hands or otherwise deal the housing bubble a lethal blow.

5.  Oil will trade between $34 and $55 for years.  We are at the high end of the range and struggling to stay there.
I share neither Mr. Rosenberg's optimism nor his agenda.

"C1896 Pistol Main article: Mauser C96 

Mauser C96 in 9mm Luger
Mauser branched out into pistol design in 1896, producing the C96, commonly known as "broomhandle," designed by the three brothers Fidel, Friedrich, and Josef Feederle[24] (often erroneously spelled "Federle"). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mauser

Comment: Good summary of the opportunities available so people have alternatives to driving. Yes, not everyone can bike or walk. Yet in some areas, this has been addressed better than in other areas.
Look around folks. Lack of the simple exercise of walking is killing us. Yet despite a means of transportation refined over 3.5 million years, you'd think people believe their care is an appendage.
Short distance trips by walking or biking are the low-hanging fruit. Yet, many people will drive if the distance is more than one-quarter mile. Thus the phrase, "we might as well walk", as if walking is some kind of secondary option. 
The challenge is making it easier to walk than to drive. To make roads safer to walk, cars have to be slowed, and in some cases with Oak downtown, narrowed. This will tick off motorists who don't plan ahead. How many people plan on adding even 5 minutes to their trip in case there is any delay? We leave at the last minute, the fume over unforeseen traffic problems.

I'm of the opinion that if someone wants to set up a trust fund for their children, they should do it themselves rather than count on the Government to do it for them. 

My recommendation?  Pay out one third of the fund to the people as a lump. That's about $25K per person. They can take it in cash and blow it or leave it in an investment fund run by the PFC. We need some new ideas. The current ones aren't making headway.

Comment: Very interesting discussion from multiple perspectives.
As an experienced small landlord who owns both pre-1991 and newer rental properties, my thought process for raising rents each year includes the following:
1. do I want these tenants to stay on? If so, I will not raise rent (even on a newer unit) to a level that might induce them to leave.
2. are costs increasing at a higher rate than the rental  guideline? For older units, this may mean a conversation with the tenants about negotiating a higher rent than the guideline allows, but that still makes sense for them, while maintaining the viability of my investment. This balance is important, as my alternative (selling the property) would both be expensive for me and put the tenants at risk of having to move.

Comment: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arab_slave_trade

"The trade of slaves across the Sahara and across the Indian Ocean also has a long history, beginning with the control of sea routes by Muslim Arab and Swahili traders on the Swahili Coast during the ninth century (see Sultanate of Zanzibar). Comment: There is plenty of room for disagreement on these issues but why does Mr. Schwab always fall back on unwarranted personal attacks?  The arts are not directly related to the Federal budget any more than reducing the size of the EPA when it comes to providing public services. Comment: How is it an "erosion of privacy" when the police had to obtain a judicially authorized assistance order in order to use the technology tool against the suspects?

We have had comparable judicial requirements for wiretapping for over half a century. So it is hard to see how, in this case, there is any worsening erosion of privacy. 

If anything, it is an ongoing level of reasonable investigation going back decades and requiring, appropriately, judicial permission for certain tools to be used.

As a citizen, I am pretty sure there are several ways for agents to use electronic methods to survey me. It is one thing to demand that agents must receive from a judge the permission needed to use the methods and must show to the judge their evidence of suspicion to warrant permission.

It is another thing to demand that the agents explain to me and to publicize how the methods work at a technical level. That is a recipe for crippling each electronic method the first time it appears in court.

Comment: The most common way to fish for crappie is to use a very light lead-head jig with a plastic hula skirt attached (I like fluorescent green), either cast and retrieve slowly or just drop to the bottom and jig. Crappie are easy to catch during spawning just like any other fish, but in summer they hang out in colder pockets of water. They are also called "paper mouths" because their bite is almost undetectable, and it's easy to tear the hook out of their mouths. Jigging helps to set the hook. Retrieve them slowly and use a net so their mouths don't tear from lifting them out of the water. Sometimes you can catch a lot of them.

Comment: [We have one of the last centrist politicians on the red side.]
As a centrist I wouldn't call Murkowski a centrist.  Firstly, centrism isn't "middle of the road," "fence-sitting," etc. but a ideology that we as a nation and as a result of our governing system got to where we are with good reason.  This generally means resisting any big shifts one way or the other.
Secondly, Murkowski is consistently conservative in about 90% of her stances.  There are two areas she consistently breaks from her party though.  Namely reproductive rights and hate crimes.  But for gun rights, gay marriage, pro-development, etc. etc. etc. even affirmative women's rights Murkowski votes alongside most Republicans.
I don't think Murkowski's issue on the Republican healthcare bill is shifting the healthcare issue a good distance to the right so much as the disregard for proper process and inclusion of viewpoints.

Comment: Not true, Klastri, not true.  DACA has been challenged.  You might want to check Texas vs United States.  In February 2015, a U.S. District Judge in Texas issued a preliminary injunction against DACA.  The Obama administration appealed to the Fifth U.S, Circuit Court of Appeals, which, in November 2015, a three-judge panel ruled against the Obama administration by upholding the lower court’s injunction against DACA and another program created by Obama, called Deferred Action for Parents of Americans.   The Obama Administration then appealed to the Supreme Court.  On June 23, 2016, the Supreme Court announced it had deadlocked 4-4 in a decision that left in place the lower court’s preliminary injunction blocking the program.  A petition for rehearing filed by the Obama administration was denied by the court on October 3, 2016.   http://www.scotusblog.com/case-files/cases/united-states-v-texas/

Comment: I don't think JP is suggesting anonymous comments are either less or more "valid."  I think he was suggesting that they might be just a tad cowardly.  It's easy to throw a stone from the center of a mob. It's far more difficult to step out front, throw that stone and accept that you will be recognized and, possibly, face some consequences for your actions.  

As I've often said, if I were afraid or ashamed of what I was going to say and felt it necessary to make the comment from the cover of anonymity, I wouldn't make the comment.  JP Wilson uses his or her name and accepts the accountability which comes with making statements and expressing opinions.  Others, such as yourself, are unwilling to do that.  

I've, over the 45 years we've lived in Oregon, received dozens of "hate letters" reacting to my letters and OpEds.....all anonymous of course.  I accept that as the price of openly expressing my views.  Anonymous posters aren't willing to pay that price.  I feel that is cowardly.....

Comment: I don't see how race needs to be a factor here.  An individual that has a poor work history and/or an unmanaged substance abuse problem will be more likely to re-offend. Some have no interest in trying and others have simply given up due to seemingly insurmountable adversity.  This is compounded by a society that doesn't want to forgive anything you've ever done.

If we want to actually fix our legal system, we need to change it from a system based on what can be proven to what actually happened.  This means actually holding both the LEOs and DAs accountable for ethically questionable behavior.  For example, hiding or ignoring evidence that could suggest innocence should be a serious crime.  We shouldn't convict or sentence based on our passions but instead solely based on the heinousness of their crime, with very limited consideration of the circumstance.

Comment: There are plenty of parties. Seems like a dozen or more on the last presidential ballot.

But it’s not likely that any of them will rise to majority power. A system in which a majority sets the rules, agenda and operations of a given legislative house means those of like-minded ideology will tend to coalesce around either a conservative or a liberal party candidate, leading to one or the other gaining given seats and a majority.

While it’s possible for a third or fourth party to win seats, to win broader support and capture a legislative majority requires an ideology with broader appeal across multiple issues. Libertarian, Green, Reform and Bull Moose parties tend to be born of activism on singular issues.

Comment: It is common for us to view the loss of control as a loss of dignity.  It is not so. Our loss of dignity as humans comes when we fail to love.  
In the face of suffering, we are called to love, to reach out in compassion and to "suffer with" another.
Independence and our need for control can stand in the way of our accepting the love of another.  When Peter refused to have his feet washed by Jesus, he was reminded that refusing this act of love would leave him on the outside.
How much greater would have been the outpouring of love, if he who committed "assisted suicide" would have accepted the care of those who loved him, and lived on in a relationship with those who chose to care for him?  Wouldn't the dignity of mankind have shined brighter? How much greater would be the dignity of the Physician had he stood at the ready to aid and comfort the man in his suffering?

The way of love is not the easy way, it is often the way of sacrifice and, of suffering, but always the way of dignity.

Comment: As to your bail point, I would think that would rely on several things. Amount of evidence against him, how much money he can come up with and the determination of the judge. Comment: Marty, let's step back.

You referenced the scripture "whatever you bind on earth shall be bound in heaven etc" as it occurs in Mt16.13-20 where that authority is given to Peter (in Greek, the ambiguous English "you" is unambiguously "you singular"--deses and luses) 

I draw your attention to the parallel passage in Mt18.15-18. In English the authority given is word for word identical but in Greek the "you" is "you plural"-- desete and lusete. And in this parallel passage, this authority is given to the ekklesia, the gathered community of believers. 

I then went on to suggest that the extrapolation of Peter in Mt16 to successive bishops of Rome is problematic ON THAT SCRIPTURE ALONE; whereas the extrapolation of Mt18 from the ekklesia to the Church as the entire community of the believers ON THAT SCRIPTURE ALONE is not problematic.

How subsequent ecclessiologies over time deal with these texts is a further relevant question.

Do we disagree on this minimalist proposition?

Comment: The thing I don't understand is how a pension that someone else own's can even be valued as such.  For example:

Person A: Saves $2M over a lifetime for retirement (e.g., business owner, no other retirement).  Pays out 4% per annum or $80K per year.  When he dies, he still has the $2M pot of money (or his heirs do) assuming it is in equities and not an insurance policy.

Person B:  Gets a defined pension benefit of $80K.  Assume this is 4% of the pension funds, which would be $2M.  When the person dies the owner of the pension fund (the $2M) stays in the pot.  If the province, then in the provincial pot, etc.

Therefore, Person A really does have an asset of $2M, but Person B doesn't have any asset when they die.

There must be an accounting reason that full value can be assumed to be an asset for a defined pension plan, but I don't understand why.  Would really love to have some enlighten me on this.  Is it just an accounting thing as I see no practical value after death.

Thanks!

Comment: Delta Junction author Judy Ferguson has published two volumes from her extensive oral history interviews with Alaska Natives.  A number of the people who shared their stories spoke about the physical and sexual abuses and the attacks on their cultures that they experienced in boarding schools.  It's a very dark period in Alaska's history and it's something we white Alaskans need to recognize and understand.  The long term consequences are still being felt in Native communities.

Both books are exceptional, and Judy's work putting them together has been a gift to all Alaskans.

https://judysoutpost.com/

Comment: It would be my guess ( I'm not an economist), that much of Canada's good growth numbers in recent quarters is a direct result of the real estate market in the GTA. Because Toronto and surroundings have such a heavily weighted economic impact on Canada, its construction boom, and the consumer spending as a result of the 'wealth effect' from 30% asset appreciation in a single year have driven this growth. It's certainly not from wage growth in Canada which I believe is in the neighbourhood of 1.5% (compared to 2.5% in the U.S.). We'll see in the next six months what happens in Toronto housing market as to whether the good times continue to roll. 
One also can expect that gov't spending and their accompanying deficits have contributed to recent growth. Nothing like an extra 25-30 billion in additional expenditures to 'kick start' the economy. (Irony intended.)
Both, of course, are debt fuelled growth and have consequences.

   Our parish has a very large proportion of highly educated people, who are extraordinarily faithful and active in the church. They have been able to stay in the church with the benefit of wonderful priests, by learning to ignore theological and governance problems and focussing on non-controversial issues of personal spiritual growth, church maintenance, and modest charitable works. That restricts it to being a niche church, a tiny fraction of the population in the area.

   This is fine for some of us, but doesn't approach the radical sacrifice and evangelism Pope Francis has called for. Nor does it appeal to or meet the needs of the vast majority of Millennials.

Comment: Paul, you raise many points important at both the local and national level.  You are right, I believe, that extreme individualism without a cooperative approach isn't productive.  However, I'd say Oregon's traditional individualism does include a strong  sense of community going back to pioneer times, especially  "loyalty to friends."  While every individual is expected to do one's best, friends and neighbors are quick to pitch in when trouble arises.
I was blessed to have grown up in small towns in Oregon and I recall that community spirit fondly.  This usually led to a strong sense of "team spirit", as we see reflected in the battles over school mascots.  In fact, the downside is the tendency to be "robust against foes", which can lead to hostility towards outsiders or those who are different.
But you have asked a key question: "What do Oregonians have in common?" Ah, that's another story!

Instead he remained active in the parliament he loved until his death, winning 4 more elections in Prince Albert and dying a month short of 84 in 1979 while working on parliamentary papers in his study.

Diefenbaker knew that all countries have some sort of government but only a fortunate and free minority have a democratic, effective parliament holding governments accountable, offering voters real choices in representatives and policy, and protecting peoples' rights and freedoms.

Comment: Why not send the special session to the area between (and including) Cantwell, Denali, McKinley Village, and Healy?  There are a lot of hotels opening up now in the area, and they won't have that much heavy traffic (their heavy time is June through July), and they should have a number of larger spaces that could hold the legislature.  As a bonus this area is halfway between the two largest cities, near the center of the state, and accessible by rail, road, and air (even smaller jets).  The state might get a great deal on rates just for the fact of them showing up would draw attention to the area for tourism purposes.  Kinda a win-win all around.

Note: I do not have any financial interests in the area.  In the early 2000's I drove a delivery route through the area (between ANC and FAI) dropping off at many of the hotels, lodges, and stores there.  I always thought all the hotels and lodges closed all winter was a waste of a resource.  To me it would be good for special sessions.

Comment: This is very much yet another case where the Constitution is in conflict with itself.  
In one area, it indicates that MPs are appointed by the various political parties: by implication, that would indicate that the parties "own" their MP contingent, who thus have no option, but to "always vote at their parties' call, and never think of thinking for themselves, at all".  
In another section, the same Constitution states that MPs are elected “to represent the people and to ensure government by the people under the Constitution”.  If there is a perception that the interests of "the people" conflict with those of "the party", the MPs would logically be required to vote against their party.  
There is a very serious conflict of interests here.

Comment: This is problematic for several reasons.

Firstly, as the article points out, the cost to the employer is significant--having to hire and train someone, only to terminate them 18 months later.  In the meantime, you'll have muddled through with a less-than-stellar staff.  (The pool of people wanting 18-month contracts is small.)

Secondly, many simply won't come back (but of course won't tell you until month 17).

What this all adds up to is, a disincentive to hire women, particularly those in the 25 to 35 age bracket.  The risk of them being gone for 3 of the next five years (because most women don't have just one child) is too high.

From the worker's perspective, they will have been out of the game for so long, that their skills will likely have eroded.  They've become less valuable.

It seems to me that better child care is a better answer.  Help workers have a work AND a home life, rather than helping them to choose one over the other.

Comment: Equality of outcome has always been more of  a left wing view, and equality of opportunity a right wing view.

I don't think that either works in its pure form.  On one side (left) you have communism where there is no drive to succeed and a whole host of societal and human problems.  On the other side (right) you have a cruel Darwinian system in which what you get is wholly dependent on how well you perform, and not everyone is capable of performing equally. 

Like anything, the answer is likely somewhere in between with both at 
 possibilities play at times.  My view is that equality of opportunity should be paramount and the "default" position, with principals of equality of outcome applied selectively when needed to address specific societal problems (such as access to basic needs, etc).

Same thing with Hawaii.  The coup organizers took over the government because they had the power to take over the government.  America annexed Hawaii because they had the power to annex Hawaii.  The State of Hawaii exists because it has the power to exist.  No other reason.

Comment: I suspect that there are structural barriers to effective R&D in Canada.

One is the difficulty to focus enough ideas in one place in such a big country, and with so much our our economy tied to resource extraction.

The governments' unhelpfully allow companies a lot of latitude in terms of nondisclosure and noncompete agreements tying employees' abilities to bounce ideas around.  Really effective clusters like Silicon Valley grew in regions that restricted such limits.

Finally, we Canadians may be too darned polite to challenge each other's ideas.

Comment: Nope.  

In BC the Law Society does not set lawyers' fees and there are no fixed rates for legal services although there are maximum allowable percentages in respect of some contingency fee agreements ( personal injury or wrongful death).

Although not a legal requirement to have a fee agreement in writing (except in the case of a contingency fee agreement) I always prepared a fee agreement for every client that was individualized for the type of case and billing method (fixed fee, hourly rate, etc.).

One of my longtime clients once asked me to help his brother whose company had received a huge bill based on hourly rates from a big firm which was roughly equivalent to the entire dollar value of the dispute.  I went through the bill and yellow highlighted every entry that was "intra-firm" - such as consult with partner, consult with associate, meet with partner, meet with associate , instruct a paralegal, etc..  That took care of about 3/4 of the bill and the Registrar disallowed all.

Comment: "Creative destruction" - this is an old notion much used by acquisition and merger "geniuses", and in many cases it makes sense, saves a few jobs (though fewer worker pensions) and makes bundles of money for those with the leverage to purchase seriously frayed businesses, which some would say, described GM and Chrysler. At the beginning of a years-long recession, 2009 wasn't the right time to pull the rug out from under millions of workers in a region we call "The Rust Belt".

Your admirable (though speculative) future industries and products can still come about through hard work by the private sector, most likely subsidized to some needed extent by the federal government.

Comment: In the 1980s, the average Canadian saved 20% of their pay for retirement.
Today that number is 2.5% (plus CPP). 

5 years ago the average Canadian had $160k in their RRSP at retirement.
Today the average Canadian retires with < $60k in their RRSP and other savings (TFSA etc) - neither includes housing assets

10 years ago, the government of Canada spent $10b/yr on OAS. This year the number is over $45 billion. GIS is growing at a similar rate. Part of that is demographics but the rest comes from people not saving and becoming reliant on retirement welfare after 65. 

Most complain about gold plated public service pensions but those pensions are funded by 35 years of 15-23% payroll deductions. As for gold-plated, the average OMERS pension is $24k/yr, the average teacher pension is 48k/yr, which includes their CPP. That's a good retirement income but comes after 35 years of saving over $12k/yr plus $2400 into CPP. The average Canadian saves $1200/yr plus $2400 into CPP.

Comment: I have to disagree with you.

You can only squeeze in so many patients in one day before the quality of care  suffers.  I've seen it in a doctor's office where patients are treated like they're on a conveyor belt.  In and out fast.  It gave me the impression the doctor was more interested in cranking up the billings.

If I am going to see a doctor to assess a problem, I don't think I would be comfortable with a doctor who rushes through their diagnostic exam just so they can fill up their roster with more patients.  Such a situation will bring  liability issues and malpractice lawsuits if misdiagnosis leads to something more serious.  Will the government take on such liabilities?

Comment: As kids in Wheatridge in the 70’s, my brother and I had the News and Post paper routes in our neighborhood. RMN before school, Post after school. When it started we each had one, but then we just combined the effort. For what it’s worth, we had a lot more RMN subscribers. Back then, we went door to door in a never ending cycle to collect the subscription money. Amazing how many people would hide or not answer the door to stiff a little kid. Sometimes they’d call one paper and cancel a subscription without paying, then call the other paper to sign up. When that happened, we’d both show up at their door and explain that “until you pay my brother what you owe him, you aren’t getting either paper delivered”. After we did that about half a dozen times, we never had to do it again.

Comment: Basically there are 3 groups of PERA stakeholders - employers, employees and retirees.  The PERA trust fund is in trouble for 3 main reasons - PERA members are living longer, economic stagnation as far as the eye can see, and legislative meddling and mismanagement.  There is a matter of fairness here, as I'll try to explain.  It is fair that employees pay more to make up for demographic change, or increased life spans.  It is fair that retirees give back some of their COLA to make up for a changing, slower growing economy.  It is also fair that employers (i.e., taxpayers) contribute more to help mitigate legislative mismanagement.  I and many others who have charted PERA's course over the years can cite many examples of mismanagement.

So, as I have outlined above, fairness dictates that all three parties contribute towards funding PERA's unfunded liability.  Employees should contribute more due to demographic change, retirees due to economic change, and employers due to mismanagement.

Wrights Crossing is unusual in that people of widely divergent political ideologies and opinions oppose it for the same reasons. For example, I oppose it for the same reasons as all three county commissioners. Its not needed, it would cause enormous problems, suck up all county planning energy for years, isn't consistent with the Growth Management, and convert over 1/3 of a square mile of farmland into classic urban sprawl.

Interesting Historical Fact: The term "silent majority" was made famous by Richard Nixon's VP Spiro Agnew. Agnew was the second VP to resign from office, but the only one to exit in disgrace. Agnew was investigated on suspicion of conspiracy, bribery, extortion and tax fraud. He took a plea deal for one felony count of tax evasion that included his leaving office. Credit to Wikipedia.
